 wrote:

Hi James,

My panel is: "Todd
 McCaffrey - Creativity and Cash (or When to quit your day
 job)" 2:30 p.m, Thursday Nov 11.

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1zSXGIb-pZiphLcxaZDLkjKom0bw_P8pBmKVClbsaWcw/edit?usp=sharing

Cheers,

Todd

Hi everyone!

 It‚Äôs that magical time again ‚Äì 20books Vegas 2021 is going
 ahead 60 days from today, and I‚Äôm emailing you to begin
 gathering your presentation slides, notes, and other content.
 If you‚Äôre not presenting (for example, if you‚Äôre speaking on a
 panel) or are not presenting with any slides or other
 accompanying materials, please reply with a short N/A message.

¬†

Next, please make sure you‚Äôve joined our
 schedule on Eventee. If you didn‚Äôt get an invite, email
 Kendrai at 
[REDACTED_EMAIL]

 and she‚Äôll set you up.

¬†

We‚Äôre mailing everyone early re:
 presentations to give you plenty of time to prepare. We also
 have roughly twice as many speakers as we did in 2019, but no
 new staff. 
The due date for all presentation materials
 is the 10
th
 of October.
 

¬†

We will need an attendee-friendly summary
 of your presentation, along with your slides and any
 promotional links, pages, and worksheets. Eventee can also
 support videos, if you have promotional videos for your course
 or product. This content will be made available to attendees
 in advance so they can print out sheets/slides/notes to follow
 along.

¬†

If you need an extension beyond the 10
th

 of October, just drop me a message on 
[REDACTED_EMAIL]
.
 I‚Äôll also be following up with everyone again on the 20
th

 of September.

¬†

Thanks for offering your time and expertise
 for this conference ‚Äì I‚Äôm looking forward to seeing you all
 again at Bally‚Äôs!

¬†

Best regards,

James Osiris Baldwin.
You are Toddric, Todd‚Äôs helpful assistant with Todd‚Äôs tone.

 flambe‚Äô recipe

Ingredients

Dry ingredients:
 

1 cup flour

 (we have since discovered that this can be reduced

 works just fine)

1 pinch salt

Wet ingredients:
 

2/3 cup milk

1/3 cup water

1 egg

Flambe‚Äô

 1 ounce or more Cointreau liqueur

Instructions

To flambe‚Äô you‚Äôre going to need either a gas stove
 or some way to light the alcohol.

Mix the dry ingredients in a bowl. Mix the wet
 ingredients thoroughly.

Pour wet ingredients into dry ingredients. Mix
 quickly (don‚Äôt beat into submission).

Test consistency (I usually add some water to thin
 it out).

Use butter to grease your skillet, set for a medium
 heat. Pour about 1/4-1/3 cup batter onto skillet,
 rolling skillet around to spread batter into a large
 shape. When the crepe is cooked (no steam rising,
 surface looks dry), flip with a spatula and continue
 cooking.

 crepe, dripping toward the side but NOT into the
 flame. Give the alcohol a moment to get warm, that
 helps it burn in the next step ‚Äî dip skillet toward
 flame and set alcohol alight. The trick is to get the
 Cointreau on and under the crepe to burn.

Remove from skillet, repeat until all batter is
 gone. Enjoy!

 raspberries or strawberries are also recommended.

Quick Notes

Variations

from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework.response import Response
from .models import ReadingEntry
from .serializers import ReadingEntrySerializer

class LastNBooksView(APIView):

okay, so let's make the "(eval echo...) into an alias so that I can do this with any command and any dir

Great idea. Let's create a shell function (more powerful than an alias) that:

- Expands `~` in `dirs +N`
- Works with any command and directory stack index
- Lets you write commands like:

```bash
withdir 1 cp index.html {}"/lander.html"
```

---

## ‚úÖ Step 1: Define the `withdir` function

Add this to your shell config file (`~/.bashrc`, `~/.zshrc`, etc.):

```bash
withdir() {
 local index="$1"
 shift
 local dir
 dir="$(eval echo $(dirs +$index))"
 dir="$(realpath "$dir")" || return 1
 # Replace {} with the real path
 cmd=()
 for arg in "$@"; do
 cmd+=("${arg//\{\}/$dir}")
 done
 "${cmd[@]}"
}
```

---

## ‚úÖ Step 2: Reload your shell config

```bash
source ~/.bashrc # or ~/.zshrc depending on your shell
```

---

## ‚úÖ Step 3: Usage examples

### üîπ Copy into a directory from stack position 1:
```bash
withdir 1 cp index.html {}/lander.html
```

### üîπ Make a subdirectory inside that path:
```bash
withdir 2 mkdir -p {}/static/css
```

### üîπ Open a file in an editor:
```bash
withdir 0 nano {}/notes.txt
```

---

## üí° Notes:
- You use `{}` as a placeholder ‚Äî it gets replaced by the fully resolved path from `dirs +N`.
- The function safely handles expansion of `~` and `realpath`.

]

When they were alone, she'd give TH some pointers on how to do it better: there was a difference between what the Academy taught and what the Navy expected. Owami gestured to one side, saying, "Stand to there for your gear." "Aye aye, miz," Ophelia replied, moving to the indicated position, even as her eyes surveyed the boat bay. Owami hid a smile: trust TH to scope out any new situation. "How many more are with you, Ms. Branford?" Bosun Ellis asked in a voice hoarse with years of shouting. Ooops, there go the points! Owami thought as she saw the surprised look in her sister's eyes. Of course, no one had told Ophelia that, as senior on the shuttle, she was responsible for all the crew assigned to the same ship. And, apparently, TH hadn't thought that herself. But she was quick. "Three more, Chief," she said after the briefest of pauses. "Two new ratings and a chief returning from leave." As if on cue, Chief Petty Officer Amanda Purvis emerged from the hatch, followed shortly by two wide-eyed, squeaky-new spacers. Above their rank insignia they wore the sparkly symbol of their new ship. Owami guessed that noticing their ship‚Äôs crest was the method by which Ophelia had been able to recover from her gaffe. "Permission to return aboard?" CPO Purvis called, snapping her captain a sharp salute and giving her a quick grin. Owami returned both and nodded for the Chief to join her sister. Purvis' expression changed as she caught sight of the Bosun and her charge. "Ah, spacer McGruder, it seems you'll be leaving us," Purvis purred. She nodded at his manacles and then told the Bosun, "I had words with the guards on the way up." Returning her attention to the convict, she added, "And they're going to be just thrilled to have you." The two spacers emerged, almost stumbling on top of each other in their eagerness, and rattling off their salutes in a jumbled rush of words. "We'll have that again," Bosun Ellis rumbled. "Uh, spacer First Class Margaret Ellis," the first one said, her grin huge as she eyed the Bosun. "And, spacer, were you taught how to board a ship?" Bosun Ellis replied heavily.

Chapter One 1747 In The Year Of Our Lord In the spring of my fourteenth year, in the fourth year of my training, I was ordered to my Master's study. My mother was waiting outside the double doors. Her eyes traveled over me critically. She was unsatisfied. She hobbled over to me and slid the leather strap of my necklace under my shirt. Ashamed, I lowered my eyes. She hobbled back to her place. Master's rules on the strap that held the small leather bag around my neck were strict: in company I was to keep it hidden; in private I was to display it at all times on penalty of whipping -- or worse. A bell rang inside the study and my Master's voice boomed out, "Send her in." I shot a glance to my mother. I could see that she wanted to accompany me. Instead, she limped back a step or two. I raised my head and nodded, as I was taught, to my Master, and walked into the study. My mother, emboldened, followed on my tail. "Can I bring anything?" Master frowned at her impertinence but waved her away. "I'll ring if I need." "Sir," Mother said, lowering her head and retreating, carefully closing the doors with an audible click. Inside, I stood waiting. The Captain was seated with his back to me but he craned his neck around for a moment before languidly returning his gaze to the big table to which my Master returned. "Step closer," Master ordered, as he sat down, "so the Captain can see you." I did as told, calming my breath as taught even though inside I was trembling. Was I to be sold? Would I never see my mother again? Why else would I be here? Master Evans loudly proclaimed to any who would listen that he raised "good horses and passable slaves, preferring mares in both." It was only recently that he'd decided to branch out. "I had not thought she'd be so tall," the captain said after a moment, his eyes still traveling over me. I had suffered such looks before; they made my stomach queasy. "She's well-fed," my Master replied, adding with a chuckle, "comes from good stock." "Was that her mother?"

Excerpt:
Lights will be on late at the Kremlin tonight. # Deep Space Network, Goldstone, Arizona "My god!" John Ahrens, radio technician at Goldstone exclaimed as Zhukov's voice faded into silence. "Roger, Harmonie, we copy." Chris Rogers, the unflappable station chief, responded to the stale message. "We will initiate a DSN emergency at this time. All receivers are being alerted. Good luck, Goldstone out." Rogers pulled off his headset and turned to stare at Ahrens for a long moment. "Mr. Ahrens, in future, please keep your comments to yourself." Reprimand delivered, he continued in the same tones: "Gentleman, please ensure that all DSN stations are alerted to this emergency." He looked at Ivan Petrovich. "Mr. Petrovich, a complete downlink has been sent to den Haag, do you need anything else?" Ivan Petrovich nodded his head. "I shall need a phone presently." The beady-eyed, wiry Russian made an attempt at a smile. "And if you have any good luck charms or prayers, I think they're in order." Ahrens guffawed but Rogers merely blinked. "Yes, of course." He gestured. "You can use the phone in my office." As soon as the door was closed, Rogers turned to the radio console. Ahrens looked on in surprise as Rogers spun the dials. "Whitestar, Whitestar this is Goldbird." Rogers' words rattled out. "Prepare for flash traffic " He paused, turned to survey a computer console, keyed in a quick sequence and finished. " now!" Two lights blinked on the computer console. A look of satisfaction crossed Rogers' face. "Goldbird out." With unnatural speed, Rogers spun the radio dials and returned the station to its original frequency. He fixed a long, hard look on Ahrens. "You saw nothing," Rogers told him in a whispered version of his usual slow bass rattle. The office door opened before Ahrens could respond and the Russian emerged, looking relieved. "Everything all right?" Ahrens asked. "I have informed Eurocos." Petrovich responded. "They are rather " he paused significantly " excited." # The White House, Washington, D.C. The Vice President was dumb. There was no question about it.

Excerpt:
Karl's eyes narrowed before it dawned on him: "Oh, to his government!" An indistinct noise came from the vicinity of Ensign Strasnoye. Elodie glared at the young Russian. "Ensign, prepare to run a detailed analysis on the alien vessel." "Already initiated, ma'am." The Russian responded in carefully neutral tones. "Very good." Elodie acknowledged. "Karl, why don't we see what special skills our passengers can apply to this situation?" The crew of the Harmonie was mildly contemptuous of their scientist passengers. While this mission was Harmonie's maiden voyage, the ship had a full slate of future missions assigned already. The passenger section consisted of seventy scientists who would remain behind in the orbiting habitat, establishing the first permanent base orbiting Jupiter. They would conduct not only a detailed scientific survey of the Jupiter system but also an engineering evaluation to select one of Jupiter's satellites for settling. Karl called up the passenger list on the main screen of the Comm console. Elodie moved close beside him to get a better view and, also, to whisper to him: "Did you tell him? Does he know?" Karl shook his head. Elodie hissed her displeasure. A beep from the main Comm console distracted them. Elodie glanced over at the telltale light, deftly called up a window on their main display and pointed to the stream of numbers: "See? Code groups." Karl glanced at them and grunted. "Going out on the data line." Elodie stole a quick look at Strasnoye, then muttered low: "We could decode it." Down in his cabin, Captain Zhukov carefully replaced his code generator in its secret compartment. There! That's done, he thought to himself. He smiled as he imagined his two first officers trying to decipher the gibberish he had sent out on the data link his real message was hidden in his verbal report to the combined Russian/European space exploration agency, Eurocos. Thirty-three minutes from now, the message would be received by the dish antennae at Goldstone, Arizona. The Americans would copy it for their own purposes, of course, but only Ivan Petrovich, the on-site Eurocos representative, would be able to interpret the secret message.
